summary: “The Dothraki follow strength above all, Khaleesi. You’ll have a true khalasar when you prove yourself strong and not before,”...
body:
“The Dothraki follow strength above all, Khaleesi. You’ll have a true khalasar when you prove yourself strong and not before,” Jorah says to Daenerys. 

I think the Dothraki way and “Fire and Blood” actually mesh quite well together. 

Dany can’t be a Queen who keeps the peace and rules the people because she’s a Khaleesi.

tags: but none of this matters coz show!writers would do whatever they want anyway
sorry anon... for the incredibly late reply
summary: I like Tyrion in the show, but not really in the books. But if he really goes and works for Cersei and betray Dany I won't be...
question: I like Tyrion in the show, but not really in the books. But if he really goes and works for Cersei and betray Dany I won't be sad about his death or angry with Dany. If he really choose Cersei, the sister who tried to kill him so many times and that hates him with all her heart over the person who believed in him. If he really choose Cersei when she is ready to betray all of them, well, he won't be as clever as I thought he was, he was looking for it
answer:
I like Tyrion in the show, but I love Tyrion in the books. I really love conflicted characters, characters questioning morality, and heroes who are like ugh-there-are-no-heroes-i’m-a-cynical-bitch, but is actually a big heroic softie inside. It’s my favourite trope!

However, the problem with the show is that, they haven’t set it up. Where is their difference in ideologies? Heck, they even have the same motives and want the same thing!

Why would Tyrion betray Dany? Because he finds a pregnant Cersei more innocent than a non-pregnant one? seems a bit iffy to me.

Now, if it is about saving the life of a lannister child (I don’t think the kid will be born though, Cersei’s prophecy remember???), Dany doesn’t harm kids!! She literally doesn’t harm the kids of her enemies that she held as hostage, for god’s sake! She is incredibly maternal - that’s one of the main characteristic of Daenerys Targaryen. Even show!dany doesn’t harm the kid who tried to assassinate her. I’m pretty sure, if Tyrion just talked to Dany to save his niece/nephew, she would… She might keep them as a ward/hostage, or at the maximum exile them, but she won’t kill a kid!

Now, if it is about Dany using her dragons in war - I still don’t get it! Tyrion loves dragons! He also has no compunctions about burning people during war, he used wildfire!!  So… I just don’t get it. 

That being said, if Tyrion still betrays Dany and ends getting execute, I’d still be sad. Because I don’t consider Tyrion’s worth based on his utility to Dany - on how clever he is, or how successful his war campaign is. I’d definitely be frustrated with him (why would you do such a dumb move, tyrion???), but not enough to wish him death, tbh. I mean, Ned Stark did some pretty dumb things, yet his death is considered a tragedy.

But more than “deserving death” or not, the point is - even if Tyrion betrayed Dany, why would she execute him??? What did Tyrion do that Ser Jorah hasn’t already done? But Dany only exiles Ser Jorah and executes Tyrion? It just doesn’t make sense to me.

Unlike what the fandom thinks, Dany is incredibly empathetic, even to her political opponents, and even to her betrayers. (Compared to other rulers, she might as well be a saint.)

I mean, Dany considers Jorah as one of the reasons Rhaego died:

No, she shouted, or perhaps she only thought it, for no whisper of sound escaped her lips. She was being carried. Her eyes opened to gaze up at a flat dead sky, black and bleak and starless. Please, no. The sound of Mirri Maz Duur’s voice grew louder, until it filled the world. The shapes! she screamed. The dancers!

Ser Jorah carried her inside the tent.

 Darkness, Dany thought. The terrible darkness sweeping up behind to devour her. If she looked back she was lost. “My son was alive and strong when Ser Jorah carried me into this tent,” she said. “I could feel him kicking, fighting to be born.”

 Ser Jorah had killed her son, Dany knew. He had done what he did for love and loyalty, yet he had carried her into a place no living man should go and fed her baby to the darkness. He knew it too; the grey face, the hollow eyes, the limp. “The shadows have touched you too, Ser Jorah,” she told him. The knight made no reply.

And then she realises that Jorah is in love with her (not as one loves a queen, but a woman), Jorah forcibly kisses her, literally tries to alienate her from any and all male attention, gives her bad counsel (out of jealousy), and then she finally realises that Jorah had been sending information about her, and she had still intended on pardoning him - but then Jorah acted as an entitled jerk and demanded that Dany pardon him, and so Dany punished him. Still, she does not kill him… but rather exiles him (and she hopes that he would get to go home, as it was his dearest wish).

“I know you betrayed me.” She touched her belly, where her son Rhaego had perished. “I know a poisoner tried to kill my son, because of you. That’s what I know.”

“No … no.” He shook his head. “I never meant … forgive me. You have to forgive me.”

“Have to?” It was too late. He should have begun by begging forgiveness. She could not pardon him as she’d intended.

[…]

“The gods do nothing without a purpose, they say. You did not die in battle, so it must be they still have some use for you. But I don’t. I will not have you near me. You are banished, ser. Go back to your masters in King’s Landing and collect your pardon, if you can. Or to Astapor. No doubt the butcher king needs knights.”

And what’s her response when Daario says that he’ll kill him -

“You need not even say the word, my radiance. Only give the tiniest nod, and your Daario shall fetch you back his ugly head.”

“Leave him be. The scales are balanced now. Let him go home.” Dany pictured Jorah moving amongst old gnarled oaks and tall pines, past flowering thornbushes, grey stones bearded with moss, and little creeks running icy down steep hillsides. She saw him entering a hall built of huge logs, where dogs slept by the hearth and the smell of meat and mead hung thick in the smoky air. “We are done for now,” she told her captains.

She is literally hoping that Jorah gets to go home - a man who by Dany’s consciousness, tried to kill her baby once (by reporting on her), and succeeded in it later (out of love, but by taking her into the tent); a man who spied on her; a man who is jealous of her lovers; a man who kissed her forcibly; a man who uses her given name freely without her leave; a man who demanded that she forgive him.

And you’re telling me Dany will execute Tyrion for his supposed betrayal?

Even if the worst possible thing happens - Dany loses the Jonerys baby as a consequence of Tyrion’s actions (which btw, I don’t think will happen. Tyrion is NOT going to try and save Cersei’s foetus by sacrificing Dany’s foetus… nope!) - even if that happens, it is not worse than what Jorah had done. Dany might exile Tyrion if that happens, but wouldn’t execute him.
answer_abstract:

However, the problem with the show is that, they haven’t set it up. Where is their difference in ideologies? Heck, they even have the same motives and want the same thing!

Why would Tyrion betray Dany? Because he finds a pregnant Cersei more innocent than a non-pregnant one? seems a bit iffy to me.

Now, if it is about saving the life of a lannister child (I don’t think the kid will be born though, Cersei’s prophecy remember???), Dany doesn’t harm kids!! She literally doesn’t harm the kids of her enemies that she held as hostage, for god’s sake! She is incredibly maternal - that’s one of the main characteristic of Daenerys Targaryen. Even show!dany doesn’t harm the kid who tried to assassinate her. I’m pretty sure, if Tyrion just talked to Dany to save his niece/nephew, she would… She might keep them as a ward/hostage, or at the maximum exile them, but she won’t kill a kid!

Now, if it is about Dany using her dragons in war - I still don’t get it! Tyrion loves dragons! He also has no compunctions about burning people during war, he used wildfire!!  So… I just don’t get it. 

That being said, if Tyrion still betrays Dany and ends getting execute, I’d still be sad. Because I don’t consider Tyrion’s worth based on his utility to Dany - on how clever he is, or how successful his war campaign is. I’d definitely be frustrated with him (why would you do such a dumb move, tyrion???), but not enough to wish him death, tbh. I mean, Ned Stark did some pretty dumb things, yet his death is considered a tragedy.

But more than “deserving death” or not, the point is - even if Tyrion betrayed Dany, why would she execute him??? What did Tyrion do that Ser Jorah hasn’t already done? But Dany only exiles Ser Jorah and executes Tyrion? It just doesn’t make sense to me.

And then she realises that Jorah is in love with her (not as one loves a queen, but a woman), Jorah forcibly kisses her, literally tries to alienate her from any and all male attention, gives her bad counsel (out of jealousy), and then she finally realises that Jorah had been sending information about her, and she had still intended on pardoning him - but then Jorah acted as an entitled jerk and demanded that Dany pardon him, and so Dany punished him. Still, she does not kill him… but rather exiles him (and she hopes that he would get to go home, as it was his dearest wish).

“I know you betrayed me.” She touched her belly, where her son Rhaego had perished. “I know a poisoner tried to kill my son, because of you. That’s what I know.”

“No … no.” He shook his head. “I never meant … forgive me. You have to forgive me.”

“Have to?” It was too late. He should have begun by begging forgiveness. She could not pardon him as she’d intended.

[…]

“The gods do nothing without a purpose, they say. You did not die in battle, so it must be they still have some use for you. But I don’t. I will not have you near me. You are banished, ser. Go back to your masters in King’s Landing and collect your pardon, if you can. Or to Astapor. No doubt the butcher king needs knights.”

And what’s her response when Daario says that he’ll kill him -

“You need not even say the word, my radiance. Only give the tiniest nod, and your Daario shall fetch you back his ugly head.”

“Leave him be. The scales are balanced now. Let him go home.” Dany pictured Jorah moving amongst old gnarled oaks and tall pines, past flowering thornbushes, grey stones bearded with moss, and little creeks running icy down steep hillsides. She saw him entering a hall built of huge logs, where dogs slept by the hearth and the smell of meat and mead hung thick in the smoky air. “We are done for now,” she told her captains.

She is literally hoping that Jorah gets to go home - a man who by Dany’s consciousness, tried to kill her baby once (by reporting on her), and succeeded in it later (out of love, but by taking her into the tent); a man who spied on her; a man who is jealous of her lovers; a man who kissed her forcibly; a man who uses her given name freely without her leave; a man who demanded that she forgive him.

And you’re telling me Dany will execute Tyrion for his supposed betrayal?

Even if the worst possible thing happens - Dany loses the Jonerys baby as a consequence of Tyrion’s actions (which btw, I don’t think will happen. Tyrion is NOT going to try and save Cersei’s foetus by sacrificing Dany’s foetus… nope!) - even if that happens, it is not worse than what Jorah had done. Dany might exile Tyrion if that happens, but wouldn’t execute him.
trail.content_abstract:
I like Tyrion in the show, but I love Tyrion in the books. I really love conflicted characters, characters questioning morality, and heroes who are like ugh-there-are-no-heroes-i’m-a-cynical-bitch, but is actually a big heroic softie inside. It’s my favourite trope!

However, the problem with the show is that, they haven’t set it up. Where is their difference in ideologies? Heck, they even have the same motives and want the same thing!

Why would Tyrion betray Dany? Because he finds a pregnant Cersei more innocent than a non-pregnant one? seems a bit iffy to me.

Now, if it is about saving the life of a lannister child (I don’t think the kid will be born though, Cersei’s prophecy remember???), Dany doesn’t harm kids!! She literally doesn’t harm the kids of her enemies that she held as hostage, for god’s sake! She is incredibly maternal - that’s one of the main characteristic of Daenerys Targaryen. Even show!dany doesn’t harm the kid who tried to assassinate her. I’m pretty sure, if Tyrion just talked to Dany to save his niece/nephew, she would… She might keep them as a ward/hostage, or at the maximum exile them, but she won’t kill a kid!

Now, if it is about Dany using her dragons in war - I still don’t get it! Tyrion loves dragons! He also has no compunctions about burning people during war, he used wildfire!!  So… I just don’t get it. 

That being said, if Tyrion still betrays Dany and ends getting execute, I’d still be sad. Because I don’t consider Tyrion’s worth based on his utility to Dany - on how clever he is, or how successful his war campaign is. I’d definitely be frustrated with him (why would you do such a dumb move, tyrion???), but not enough to wish him death, tbh. I mean, Ned Stark did some pretty dumb things, yet his death is considered a tragedy.

But more than “deserving death” or not, the point is - even if Tyrion betrayed Dany, why would she execute him??? What did Tyrion do that Ser Jorah hasn’t already done? But Dany only exiles Ser Jorah and executes Tyrion? It just doesn’t make sense to me.

summary: "Any man who must say I am the king is no true king." "I was born to rule the seven kingdoms. I will take what is mine." "I give...
question: "Any man who must say I am the king is no true king." "I was born to rule the seven kingdoms. I will take what is mine." "I give you a choice, join me or die." "I will fight for the North when you bend the knee." Your girl has a big fall coming and I'm here living for it.
answer:
And here you are again!

Does context mean nothing to you people? You’re so used to reading and watching everything but what is right infront of you, you’ve actually convinced yourself she’s the big bad villian. !Newsflash! They all fall if she’s falls. Sansa, Jon, the entire North gone without her. I don’t know how long we have to beat this dead horse till you get it. She earned their loyalty she didn’t conquer them and she’s not going to conquer them. I guess this is news to no one but you and those who think like you and will hate her no matter what she does but what else is new in the world of antis. Do you guys like “hate” watch the show? You must because my girl is a big damn hero.

In season 8 sansa is officially Tully like her mother. D&D finally returning with book version where is million times explanes that Sansa is more Tully than Stark.

D&D, HBO And Michelle Clapton officially kills the theiry about Jonsa . Sansa isn’t wolf.

You can enter with Michelle Clapton Insta Account where Someone wrote that Sansa’s dress and new photo poster means that she tries to be like Cersei. And her dress style is inspired from Cersei. And Michelle liked her comentar.

Tullys are always associate with lie, betrayal … how Catelyn betrayed to Robb when she helped Jaime to escape from Riveran. We all remember absolutely identical “The King In the North “ scene in season 6 final.

If Dany’s kidnaped theory is right. There is Tyrion and Sansa’s hand.

Catelyn didn’t like Talysa/jane = Sansa will not like Dany

Catelyn helped Jaime to escape from Riveran and Rob lost his war= Sansa and Tyrion informs to Cersei about Dany’s pregnacy . Cersei send Golden Company in North to take Dany because she already had miscarriage and lost her baby. She hasn’t heir and Dany is pregnant. Jon Lost Dany and Night King attachs Winterfell. Dragons will be in mess while their mother disappear. Jon can’t control situation and they lost Winterfell too.


Parallel

summary: What I don't understand about Dany fans is why they gotta put other characters down in order to big her up. Particularly Sansa....
question: What I don't understand about Dany fans is why they gotta put other characters down in order to big her up. Particularly Sansa. Sansa didn't go through all that crap to bow down to some foreign conquerer and she won't cause she isn't as dumb as Jon. You think cause Dany is beautiful and has dragons she deserves everything and every person she meets should fall at her feet. It's gross.
answer:
I’m seriously laughing. The hypocrisy and delusional thinking never ends with you lot. I’m literally gobsmacked at the audacity to even send this lmao. Please provide the receipts. I’ll wait. And as obvious to anyone that actually watches the show how asinine your arguments are, I’m not going to even take the time to destroy each point your pulling out of thin air. I see you sent a separate ask as well. Please do something more productive with your time. And before you even think of sending this garbage to my inbox again, clean up your own fandom.

Also, little pointer, try not to destroy your own points after you just make them? You claim Dany fans put Sansa down (false btw)….then you immediately call Jon dumb and Sansa the smarter one? Sure, Jan.

summary: what's your stance on the current dany debate? you follow me so you know i'm on the anti/dark dany side but i also see you...
question: what's your stance on the current dany debate? you follow me so you know i'm on the anti/dark dany side but i also see you reblogging pro/neutral posts. you have a lot of insight on many topics so what do you think?
answer:
As for the show storyline, I consider all the debate basically a grocery raid on the aluminum aisle. Secret codes in hair braids would require actual care to set up.

The showrunners don’t.

They put their stock in sex scenes and spectacular set pieces, not careful character arcs or thoughtful themes.

It makes for great gif posts but the show is shit.

As for the books, the storyline for Daenerys pulls in mind the old adage about good intentions and the road to hell. Dany has good intentions, at least she tells herself that. The consequences of her choices and the fundamental truth (since Martin loves the unreliable narrator) of her character has a good element of debate.

Meeren remains such a malaise to muddle through, I had to force myself to read those chapters and I tend to skip them in my re-reads. It is darkness induced apathy for me, especially after the long wait for the Dance of Dragons (Martin one ups kicking the puppy with eating unborn ones!)

I just don’t care.

I do ascribe to the theory Dany will fall under shadow but not fall into it. Similar to Jon and Tyrion, they are the endgame in the salvation of the world and that path is not going to pretty. Death equals redemption, but your mileage will vary.

I am not invested in Dany or Jon or Tyrion but I have a weakness for the pretty posts.
